text: CLOSE UP: Ornate antique GRANDFATHER CLOCK strikes 2:15. The credits begin to roll. Calligraphy place cards are painstakingly hand-written in preparation for a formal reception. Servants meticulously clean an elaborate crystal chandeli Hands rapidly shine silver cutlery. Fresh flowers arranged in several enormous vases.

Kitchen clock strikes 2:15. Poultry plucked. Feathers everywhere. Steaming copper pots boiling over. Platters prepared with decorative garnish. Extravagant tiered cake is lavishly iced. A glob of frost enters a pair of puckered lips. The perpetrator, a fey,  pompous, HEAD VALET, seriously considers the texture and  flavor of the icing, then gives the PASTRY CHEF a witheri sour look. The valet, oblivious to the chef's fury, gathers a prepar silver breakfast tray and checks his pocket watch. 2:15.

Antique bedside table clock -- just past 2:15. The valet  throws open velvet drapes, sunlight FLOODS the room revea a figure sleeping soundly in a massive oak framed bed. Th valet puts down the tray, pulls back the quilt. The dozing figure gives the valet a deliberate, angry KIC Flinching infinitesimally, the valet crosses to the close selects three suits and holds them up for inspection. Fro beneath the puffiest of pillows, AN EYE reluctantly opens weary arm points decisively to the riding outfit.

The riding outfit is adorned by LEOPOLD, Duke of Albany, dashing, virile man in his 30's. GALLOPING with great aba he expertly leads his horse up hills and over hedges. He  sends gardeners shaping the grounds fleeing from his path In the background, lanterns are being strung throughout t estate. Rugs are beaten out of open windows.

Large hallway clock -- 6:15. A pair of boots track a fres scrubbed floor as Leopold heads carelessly up the stairwa Three steps behind, the valet snaps his fingers signaling the staff to clean up the mess.

Gaudily framed portraits of somber relations. A bird sits listless in a gilded cage. Hot water is poured into a bath. Carriages begin to arrive. Orchestra leader signals the musicians to play. Guests fill the ballroom in formal attire.

Leopold stares haughtily into a full length mirror. He wears only dotted linen drawers and a black silk top h of the period. He flexes slightly. The valet hastily fast a corset around his mid-section from behind. Leopold eyes his reflection seductively. He becomes bored He turns to his right. The valet spoons sorbet from a sil saucer into his mouth. He turns back to the mirror to wat himself eat. The valet pats his mouth dry. He affects a pampered STRUT, crossing the room as the val sprays a mixture of perfume and powder into the air. Leop thrusts out his arms walking through the mist, turns and  saunters back to his favorite place, in front of the mirr Finally, as if weighing a great decision, Leopold hands h hat to his valet and nods firmly into the mirror.

Fine linen undervest slides over his head. Black twilled worsted trousers pulled up to his waist. The buttoning of his hard, white, roll collar. A cream suede glove stitched in black slides over his han A perfect tight bow tie is tied around his neck. An elegant black tuxedo jacket with silk facings and tail to the knees is fitted to his torso. His hair is sleeked with oil and centrally parted. His eyebrows are brushed with a tiny silver comb. His cheeks are pinched. A red silk handkerchief is placed in the bosom of his lap Leopold stares into the mirror. The effect is DAZZLING. H raises one eyebrow. Then, in a voice you could pour over waffle:
You dance like a herd of cattle,  Miss Fairchild. You are a rare woman  who lights up the room... simply by  leaving it.
He bows. As he rises, the reflection of Leopold's UNCLE O a pampered, effectual man in his 60's, appears behind Leo in the looking glass.
Tell me Leopold, do you plan to join  us downstairs after completing this  one-sided flash of wit?
I despise affairs of this sort, Uncle  Otto. No one really listens to anyone  else. If you attempt it, you will  see why.
You judge everything too severely. I  wonder what would happen if you were  to cast that critical eye inward?
You do not wonder at all. You merely  ask in order to state your own  opinion.
We are all concerned about you.
Ahh, here it comes.

Your life does not seem to have any  direction. At the age of 25 a man is  too young to do anything well. At 35  he is too old. Now is your time to  take action. Tell me, what is it you  want to DO with your life?
(wearily) I do not know.

(just as weary) Your ignorance cramps my conversation. (he slaps Leopold's  face twice rather  quickly) Wake up! This is your one and only  life. Every man has the chance to  make a difference. DO something!
Leopold, stung, takes a moment to compose himself.
I am most grateful for your  surveillance and for your sympathy.  I assure you there is no need for  concern. I am as effectual and  attentive... as my position allows.
Life is not position, Leopold. It is  action. (he straightens  Leopold's tie) I will see you downstairs promptly.  In the appropriate frame of mind.

He leaves. Leopold stares into the mirror, snaps his fing The valet hands him a glass and pours a small shot of bra Leopold shoots him a look. The valet fills the glass high Leopold drains the glass and heads to the doorway. He  hesitates, taking a deep breath and a long pause. Finally
(grandly) Go spread joy.
Without looking back, Leopold leaves the room.

Music fills the air as the creme de la creme of Victorian society gather inside. Leopold holds a prearranged dance  card. He looks at the names and finds his first partner i MISS TREE. Leopold looks upward helplessly at an unrelent God.

A profoundly self-conscious Leopold dances energetically  into frame with MISS TREE, an ancient, elfin, yet amazing SPRY woman who gapes up at him searchingly, unblinking. Leopold opens his mouth to speak, can think of nothing  suitable to say, and clamps his mouth shut. They dance ou of frame.

Leopold dances into frame with CLARA, a BEAUTIFUL girl of 19. He glances at her and smiles. She titters, turning aw shyly. They whirl around the dance floor. His smile grows into a broad grin. Caught up in the excitement, Clara bea up at him... happily revealing a mouth full of missing, i teeth. Leopold, face frozen in a formal smile, dances on.
Leopold lumbers into frame with MISS FAIRCHILD, a woman o immense girth. With great dignity and extreme difficulty maneuvers her around the floor, looking everywhere except her enormous bosom.
You dance like an angel, Miss  Fairchild. You light up the room. I  thank you.

Miss Fairchild curtseys heavily. Leopold glances at his c sees the name Miss Serena Clacket and shudders. He spots a VERY LOVELY WOMAN hidden amongst the guests. S scribbles in a small note pad, occasionally glancing arou Hiding his dance card, he saunters over.
Good evening. I do not believe I  have had the pleasure.
The young woman stares vacantly at Leopold until she real he is addressing her. She puts her pad away.
...Julia Carlson.
Leopold takes her hand and kisses it gently.
I'm sorry. Will you excuse me?
(slightly tipsy) You are not from the area, are you?
(smiles and shakes  her head "No") Are you?
This is my estate.
Really? (looking around the  room) Well it's not home but it's much...
Leopold regards her curiously. The orchestra starts up. T is a hubbub amongst the guests.
Shocking! The TA-RA-RA-BOOM-DE-AY.
The? Oh, that's from Paris, isn't  it?
It is a scandal nonetheless.
Leopold spots Uncle Otto observing him from across the ro
Miss Carlson, do me the honor?
I'm afraid I'm not much of a dancer.
(smiling seductively) Truly I would be in your debt. Any  admonition would be erased simply by  presenting a partner as lovely as  yourself.
No, no. Really, I...

Leopold stiffly holds out his arm. A beat. Carlson, stuck takes it WITH HESITATION and is escorted to the dance flo They dance. ALL but Leopold and Carlson gaily sing "TA-RA BOOM-DE-AY." Leopold, flushed, looks quite smitten. Carls shy at first, eventually smiles brightly.
I suppose we really ought to sing  along.
(embarrassed) Oh, golly.
They half sing, half speak the TA-RA-RA-BOOM-DE-AY, their emphasis on "BOOM." Laughing giddily, their dancing becom freer, picking up speed. The room SPINS. Finally:
(breathless) Thank you for the dance. It was  lovely. I hope it wasn't too awful  for you.
Not at all. It was most enlightening.
There is a slight pause. The Grandfather CLOCK strikes  midnight.
I really must be going.
I won't hear of it.
(moving away from him) No, I'm quite late as it is.
I shall see you to the door...
(stopping him  resolutely) You're very sweet. I had a wonderful  time. (she watches him,  memorizing his face.  Then firmly) Goodbye.
Leopold takes a glass of champagne from a passing waiter. watches Carlson pass through the crowd and out the courty door. He surveys the room. After a moment he follows her.

Leopold makes his way through the manicured garden in the dark. He hears an EERIE METALLIC SOUND. He slows down, br back the thicket. The silhouette of a woman is revealed. is once again writing in her notebook.
Miss Carlson?
Carlson spins around quickly, panicked. Leopold STOPS.  Partially hidden in the brush, a sleek, oddly shaped,  MECHANICAL device. It's door open, lit from within, casti a weird glow.
Good God...
What are you...? You frightened me.
Leopold moves toward the contraption and is about to touc it...
What sort of mechanism is this?
Carlson shakes her head, unsure of how to proceed.
Answer me!
It's perfectly all right. It's...
Leopold carefully examines the apparatus, stepping inside Carlson FREEZES.
(carefully,  deliberately) Listen to me. Please. Move very  slowly. Step out of the machine.  Step out and I'll explain whatever  you want to know.
What is this? Who are you?
His hand comes to rest on a glowing red lever.
Oh, God.
She YANKS on his arm. Instinctively he pulls away,  accidentally thrusting the lever into action. Carlson fal from the machine.
(suddenly frantic) Get out of there! Get out now!
The machine LIGHTS UP.
Miss Carlson... I...
No!!!
The compartment door snaps shut.
Shit!!
There is a BRIGHT WHITE FLASH. Blackness fills the screen
The compartment door slides OPEN revealing DR. KAU, 30's, Asian doctor with a THICK BROOKLYN ACCENT. Her face full enthusiasm drops as she sees the unconscious Leopold.
Shit!!
She turns to her co-workers, warning them.
Shit!!
She looks back at Leopold.
Shit!!
Her co-workers, DR. PLODDER, austere, authoritative, DR.  DRAKE, muddled and timid, peer inside the compartment doo
Good God!
Everybody stay calm... Lock the front  door.
Dr. Drake and Kau make a move to inspect an unconscious  Leopold.
No, no, no. You mustn't touch him.  The consequences could be  catastrophic.
He could be hurt, or even dead.
...All right. Touch him.
They approach Leopold. Dr. Kau finds Carlson's note pad o the ground next to Leopold. She reads the last entry.
...But I'm stuck and it's only a  dance and he IS the seventh Duke of  Albany...
They all look at one another, then back at Leopold.
Carlson...!
(racing from the room) Give me a minute...
Shit!
KATHERINE COLES, a radiant workaholic, types frenetically into the computer while talking on the phone, trying hard not to sound upset.
Who's upset? People fall in love,  they have to climb back out. (she laughs but she  is not smiling) So, what? We'll just be friends now,  Right?
She stops typing and listens for a while. She runs her ha through her hair.

I see. Well I appreciate your honesty. (using her middle  finger she pushes up  her glasses) No. I'll just think of this as  surviving another dating accident.  Take care or good luck or whatever  I'm supposed to...
The line goes dead.
...say... Goodbye.
Dr. Plodder bursts in. Kate sees his distress and instant becomes very centered.
She's back.
(rising) That's impossible! She wasn't supposed  to return until...
Kate. It's Carlson. Something went  wrong.
He hands her Carlson's note pad. Slowly, she sits down.
...The 7th Duke...

(all business, reading  from a printout) ...of Albany. He was the... IS the  son of Emery and Eliza. He was of no  actual importance until he vanished  at the turn of the century without a  trace. It was a sensation. In the  30's they even made a movie about  him. "The Tenuous Duke" with Ronald  Coleman.
(absently) I love Ronald Coleman.
Despite much speculation and a nation  wide investigation, a body was never  found. He was never heard from again.
Until now.
There is a stunned silence. They stare at Leopold in awe.
We've altered the course of history.
We never should have started this...
Calm down.
What are we going to do? We can't  keep him here. Imagine if anyone  found out!

Think. Just, think. Rationally. Now,  no one would believe such a stupid  mistake could be made because no one  would believe any of this is possible.  So. We fix this. We keep this to  ourselves and we fix it. Fast.
They all nod in agreement.

Dr. Kau, research all our data. 1st  priority: Locate Carlson. Drake,  determine the reciprocal correlation's  connected to the 19th century. Work  24 hours a day if necessary. In the  meantime... one of us will have to  take charge of him.
She forces back panic. Only the tremor in her voice gives her away.

This is a major scientific  opportunity. It doesn't get any better  than this. Imagine. Researching the  behavior, the physical and emotional  characteristics of a century ago!  Utilizing technology available to us  today... He's a gold mine!
He's a man, Kate. Not a guinea pig.
And while he's here, he's ours. Any  volunteers?
No one moves.
We'll draw names. Whoever is is picked  will be responsible. Agreed?
They nod reluctantly. Drake writes out names and throws t in a cup. The silence becomes deafening. Finally:
I'll do it.
All the scientists face her.
You'll look after him?
No, I meant I'll pick the name.
She reaches in. They wait with mounting suspense. Finally SHE TURNS TO KATE. The scientists follow her gaze. A beat
Fine.
Leopold stirs. He blinks at the group.
Where...? What has happened?!
The doctors, caught off guard, SMILE BENIGNLY. They surro Leopold as a group, not knowing where to begin. Finally:
Your Grace... Um... Hello... Weee  aaare a smaaall part of a laaarge  research team. A project funded by  the government of the United States.
(regarding their  appearance with  distaste) Oh. Americans. I see...
Yes, um... For the past six and a  half years we've been conducting  scientific experiments on density  and flexibility in the dimensions of  time and space.
Yes, uh... Quite by accident we came  upon a formula utilizing Tachyons...  particles traveling faster than the  speed of light, which allowed us  to... fold time so to speak.
Yes. Bend it between the cracks of  the dimensions.
Yes.
They all laugh nervously. Leopold does not.
Now, while that wasn't the original  purpose of our experiment, we opted  to pursue it, well, privately, on  our own.
Borrowing funds already provided.

We journeyed to your time because it  was the quickest path to follow. We  debated long and hard whether we  should use this knowledge at all.  Believe me, it was never our intent  to disturb the past...
Merely to discover if the expedition  were possible. As your presence here  confirms... we are very disturbed.
Leopold nods at them as if they are insane.
The problem facing us is not only  HOW to get you back, but WHEN, you  see?
We certainly don't want to  miscalculate. Send you to a different  era entirely.
Leopold starts to speak.
Rest assured, no harm will come to  you. You'll be well looked after by  Dr. Coles.
Dr. Coles...? I do not follow. What  do you mean, get me back home?...  Where am I?
Awkward pause. Leopold looks carefully around the room fo the first time: modern mechanical equipment, data shiftin and changing, giant cooling devices, bright neon lighting The doctors are silent.
Answer me!... (slowly) Would you have me believe... I am  being detained, at present in the  HEREAFTER?... The time to come?
(carefully) It is the year nineteen hundred and  ninety-five.
Leopold leaps up. The doctors follow him around the room.
You're insane! All of you! This is  impossible!
Leopold, calm down!
A voyage through time! What do you  take me for? Did you bring me here  by force?
We're scientist, not seditionists.
(truly panicked) Let me out of here! I won't stand  for this another moment!
He's out the door.
Leopold moves quickly, fearfully through the darkly lit  hallway, the doctors close behind.
Leopold, wait!
You don't know what you're doing.
Just listen to what we have to say!
It is too late. Leopold throws open the door and runs  upstairs.
Blinding sunlight. Skyscrapers. Automobiles. Traffic ligh Road construction. Modern day pedestrians. Helicopters. C alarms. Leopold stands frozen, overwhelmed, taking it all in.
The doctors reach him. He collapses to the ground.
Kate and Dr. Kau talk quietly. Leopold, tightly holding o his seat and the back door, gazes out the window in utter disbelief.
Squab.
Squab?
I remember reading they ate a lot of  squab.
Squab... Do you have a squab?
(quietly. On the verge  of panic) I don't know!
Pull yourself together! (turning to Leopold) Are you all right back there?
Leopold, trembling, gapes at the sights, every day sounds magnified. Perspiration runs down the side of his face. K watches him in her rear view mirror.
You're going to be fine you know.  There's nothing to worry about. I  have everything under control.
Dr. Kau stares at Kate in concerned silence.
(quietly to Dr. Kau) We'll never get away with this.

Leopold awakens alone in his room. He sits up with a jolt His stomach sinks as he realizes THIS IS NO DREAM. He slo rises to his full stature, moving to the window he looks on the modern day city, shaking his head in awe. He makes his way to the bedroom door and tentatively touches the k There is a KNOCK on the door. Leopold JUMPS back and runs to the bed: The picture of  dignity.
How are you feeling? (no response) I thought you might like some tea.
I insist on being returned home  immediately.
I understand. We're doing our best.
I wish to speak with your employer,  Dr. Coles.
You're speaking to him.
You are not suggesting that you are  Dr. Coles?
She smiles.
Miss... uh?
Dr. Coles. If you like, you could  call me Miss Dr. Coles or if that's  too much, how about just plain Kate?
(coldly) A WOMAN of science?
Hard to believe?
But a woman's brain cannot obtain  enough knowledge to posses a truly  scientific mind.
(jotting this down) Interesting. Nevertheless, we've  come a long way baby.
(confused) Are you attempting to be humorous?
I'm attempting to be informative  it's just coming out humorous.
Leopold regards her dubiously.

(clinically) Look, modern social science clearly  states that a woman's place in society  marks the level of that civilization.  A science career for a woman is now  almost as acceptable as being a...  a... waitress. Cream and sugar?
Young lady, I... Surely it is not  expected that I remain here with you  indefinitely... Unchaperoned?
(pen poised) Does that make you nervous?
Certainly not!
(writing) Then what are you getting so red  about? It's a very large apartment...  with locks on all the doors.
The idea! My dear Miss Coles...
Dr. Coles.
Honey...

(she puts the pad  down) Let's get one thing straight right  now. My name is Kate or Katherine or  if you insist Dr. Coles. (she rises) Take a good long look, Leopold. I am  a 20th century American woman with a  Doctorate and a commission and  independence. I am not your "young  lady" or your "pretty Miss" or your  "honey." Is that clear?
Leopold watches her with great interest. Finally:
Honey... For the tea.
...I'll get it for you.
Kate grabs the teacup grandly and leaves the room.

Kate rummages through every drawer, shelf and cupboard  searching for the honey. Finally, she spots the honeybear and squeezes honey A TAD TO VIOLENTLY into the tea. She t posing "confidently" then checks her reflection in the  toaster.
Kate returns "confidently" with the tea and a plastic smi
Thank you... Has it been decided  what it is I am to do while I am  being held here?
Oh, just some laundry, the cooking,  a little light housework...
Leopold doesn't react.

(clearing her throat) I took the liberty of preparing a  simple schedule to efficiently utilize  your time while incorporating you  into my routine. (she hands him a  schedule) As you can see, my day begins with  meditation and yoga from 6:30 to  7:00.
She moves in close to him, making Leopold uncomfortable.

YOU will arise at 6:45, shower and  change and at 7:15, we breakfast  together. 7:45 we begin the days  work. At 10:45 Dr. Kau arrives to  observe you in your natural routine  as I research the data that will  enable you to return home. At 1:15  we lunch together. 2:15 you answer a  daily questionnaire, I type up my  notes. At precisely 6:15 you will  enjoy 15 minutes of FREE TIME, then,  at 6:30, I listen to Tom Brokaw while  making dinner as YOU write down any  questions that come up during your  day. At 7:00, we dine together. If  you need me at any time you may ring  this bell.
She rings a tiny dinner bell. He is about to speak.

Now, Mondays and Wednesdays I have  computer science class, Tuesdays I  have therapy. IF I have a date, I'm  usually home by 9:15. During these  periods you may read any of the books  I've picked out for you in your room.  I organize my next days work at 10:30,  11:35, David Letterman, 12:40 I'm in  bed. (she takes a breath,  smiles at him) Next day we begin again. Simple?
(after a beat, with  great dignity) ...At what time shall I WEE and POOH?
Kate is forced into a stunned silence.
Kate? I'm home.
Oh. Yes. Our chaperone is here.
Your father?
Sort of. My brother.
Visiting?

For the past two years. Charlie can  never know about this project. We'll  tell him you are a... overly  distinguished colleague staying here  as our guest. From Canada. Which  would explain your lack of familiarity  with our customs and so forth
(aghast) A CANADIAN?
Make yourself comfortable. I'll check  in on you later. I think this is  going very well, don't you?
Leopold looks at her blankly.
Okay. If you need anything, just  ring.
Kate tinkles the bell, fumbles for the knob and heads out P.O.V. still on Leopold.
(shouting) Charlie!
Leopold reacts.
(screaming just as  loud) What?
(still shouting) Come here I wanna talk to you.
Leopold listens at the door. He slowly opens it, takes tw steps out, peers around the corner, then quickly steps ba in. He takes a DEEP FRIGHTENED BREATH and slowly deflates
Charlie sits on the couch smoking a cigarette surrounded his paintings. He is a likable twentysomething with a big mouth.
What did I do?
(removing his coffee  from the table,  setting it on a  coaster) RINGS! And what did I say about you  smoking in the house?
You were against it.
Correct. You're back early. (She takes away his  cigarette)
Hey!... Are you all right? You look  funny.
Funny ha ha or funny odd?
Both.
That all depends. How was your trip?
Why?
If it was good I'll tell you the  truth. If it was rotten I'll have to  butter you up first.
Butter me up.
Have you been working out? No, I'm  really starting to see results. Are  you comfortable there on the couch?
Very.
Good. Cause you'll be sleeping there  the next few nights.
Kate!
You have to be out of here by 8 and  you can't be back before 6. We have  an important man working with us  with very unusual needs. The company  is insisting he stay here.
What about a hotel?
This man requires around the clock  attention.
I meant for me.
Thank you, Charlie. (she kisses his  forehead) I owe you one.
You owe me nine. What am I supposed  to do all day?
(as if having an  epiphany) You could get a job!
Kate, the entire point of being an  artist is that I don't have to work.  Who is this guy?
Well, I can't tell you much because...
I'm not allowed to discuss what goes  on at the office.
Well I'm not. Anyway, it might be  interesting to have someone else to  talk to. It gets so quiet around  here sometimes I feel like I've gone  deaf.
Does he have a label?
Leopold.
LEOPOLD? Is he anything like his  name?
He's exactly like his name.
Then you owe me ten.

Leopold PEEKS around the entrance to the living room.  Confident it's unoccupied, he majestically walks inside: to date gadgetry, Charlie's modern art work, bright  fashionable furniture. Leopold recoils. His eyes come to  rest on the television set. The ON OFF buttons loom large He looks around the room then brazenly presses the button ON. Instantly, REGIS and KATHY LEE loudly berate each other b an excited crowd. Leopold jumps back several feet, hands flailing in front him as if shooing away a bee. He quickly, yet cautiously, slams the power OFF.
Horrible!

He quickly scurries out the hallway. He stops abruptly. He remains very still. Composing himse he turns and deliberately faces the room. After a moment, purposefully steps back inside. He makes a large ARC around the television set, is confro by one of Charlie's sculptures and makes an ARC around th He finds himself in front of a light switch and gingerly  examines it. As he does, track lighting ILLUMINATES the r He looks at the lights then back at the switch. He flicks the lights ON and OFF, trying to figure out the precise m in the transfer of power, laughing in spite of himself. Kate and Charlie enter. They watch Leopold flicking the  lights, laughing like a madman. Charlie gives Kate a look
(explaining) He's from Canada...
Leopold sits at the head of the table, Kate and Charlie  banished to either side. Leopold chews his dinner incessa
(finally) What is this?
It's called Hamburger Helper.
It is beyond help. Please serve the  next course.
He pushes his plate away.
I'm afraid there is no next course.  If you make a list of the foods you  like, I'll pick them up at the store  for you.
Is all food here this... textured?
Mine's good.

Please understand, I am used to a  different sort of preparation. Where  I come from a proper meal is the  result of reflection and study. A  recipe is merely a theme which an  intelligent cook can plan each time  with variation.
Charlie gives Kate a look.
Several courses are served. Menus  are often prepared days in advance,  timed to perfection. It is said,  without the culinary art, the  crudeness of reality would make life  unbearable.
In Canada?
(after a beat. Firmly) In Canada.
We have a saying here. "Shake and  shake the catsup bottle, none will  come and then a lot'll."
He pours catsup on his dinner.
How interesting.
Since you're such an expert on fine  cuisine, why don't you make dinner  tomorrow night?
It should be obvious to you that I  am NOT a domestic. You may take my  plate.
I have my own, thank you.
Charlie...
Who died and made me Cinderella?
Young man, there is a distinct  impertinence to your voice.
It's part of my charm.
Suppress it.

(changing the subject) Leopold... Since you're our guest  here, there are several cultural  events you might enjoy seeing. Charlie  has season tickets to the ball game.  Perhaps you'd like to take that in?
What is it?
What is it??
Or the Opera or the Ballet?
What is it??
Charlie, there's no rule that says  everyone has to be interested in  baseball.
No, but I believe there is a rule  that says everyone has to have HEARD  of it.
Dr. Coles, your brother Charles  attitude and demeanor are  unacceptable. If I am to stay on  here you must have a serious talk  with him regarding respect and  civility.
CHARLES, could you help me with the  dessert in the kitchen?
In the kitchen?
IN the kitchen. Excuse us.
Kate and Charlie leave. The camera remains on Leopold, si alone, calmly sipping his wine. VOICE OVER FROM THE KITCH
I don't believe this guy!
Try to be nice to him.
I'm always NICE!
Please Charlie, as a favor to me.
He gives me the creeps.
Leopold reacts. He listens self-consciously.
He's different that's all.
What was that crack about domestics?
Charlie, this is important to me.
You're not going out with him, are  you?
Eeuuu! I may be desperate but I'm  not a lost cause.
Kate, this is me. I've seen the guys  you bring home.
I've done countless favors for you!  Now I'm asking for just one little  thing...
(overlapping) Oh, all right! All right! All right!
They emerge from the kitchen, beaming.
(after a beat) We forgot the dessert.
You know,... I don't know if I  mentioned it... but that is one fine  looking suit.

Radio alarm clock -- 7:45 a.m. Louis Armstrong begins to  sing, "Let's Call the Whole Thing Off." Dressed in yoga  clothes Kate sits on her bed in the lotus position. She b the gong and closes her eyes. A bell rings. Kate flinches but does not open her eyes.
(too sweetly) What is it, Leopold?
The bell rings louder, interrupting Kate's routine.
(eyes closed, screaming  like a fishwife) WHAT IS IT, LEOPOLD?!

Nonsense! Charlie, you don't want to  hurt Leopold's feelings. He's going  to think you don't want him to go.
Oh it's not that. It's just that  it's sort of a vulgar crowd, is all.  I'm not sure you'd have such a good  time.
A little ribald humor? I'm not as  big a stick in the mud as you might  think! I'd enjoy a gay night out,  kicking up my heels.
There is an awkward pause. Leopold is so enthusiastic and sincere that despite a feeling of disaster Charlie relent
Finish off your Parquet and we'll  go.
Charlie gives Kate a look of death as we:
Charlie and Leopold approach Caffeine, a trendy coffee ho Charlie looks in the window.
There they all are. Now one more  thing. Throw the words "like" and  "you know" into a sentence whenever  possible. It's how people talk today.
Proper speech does not cease to exist  simply because it is ignored.
Please?
Charles, you needn't fret. I have  the walk down pat. I will not give  myself away. Like.
(looking in the window) Oh shit! (correcting himself) Shoot.
What is it?
Patrice. See that girl? The blonde  one? She's so inconceivably hot.
Patrice, a tall blonde sits at a large round table, talki She is very beautiful.
She's very pretty.
She's mine.
Congratulations.
Ok not exactly mine. But I saw her  first.
I understand.
Okay. I guess we should go in. I  don't suppose we could tell everyone  you don't speak English?
Of course not. Let's go inside.
Leopold walks his casual walk inside, followed by a very  reluctant Charlie.
Charlie's friends are sitting at a table talking. They ar relaxed and friendly group. Charlie and Leopold approach.
(ad lib greetings) Charlie! Where've you been? etc.
Hi. Uh everyone, this is my friend,  Leo.
Hey.
Hey.
Waz up?
Waz up?
How are ya?
How are ya?
(after a beat) Leo's staying with us for a while.
Charlie pulls out a chair for Leopold but Leopold sits ne to Patrice instead. Patrice takes out her cigarettes.
May I?
Help yourself.
Leopold takes a cigarette, lights one for Patrice, then h own.
Thank you, my dear.
(at a loss) Um?... (all look at Charlie) ...I have nothing to say.
You did not tell the truth about  Patrice, Charles.
CHARLES??
What did I tell you, LEO?
He informed me you were inconceivably  HOT, but I think you're lovely.  Exceptionally lovely.
Thank you, Leo.
(to the waitress) Check please.

The subway car is inhabited solely by Leopold, Charlie, a the oldest Ukrainian woman in New York City. Despite the  fact that the train is empty, they are all seated on the  same bench. Charlie stares straight ahead refusing to even look at  Leopold. The Ukrainian woman hangs on every word.
Just drop it Leopold.
But Charles, it is so ridiculous. I  am not interested in her.
Hah!

In any case the problem is not with  me but with you. (quietly) You have no idea what it takes to go  about courting a woman. From what  I've witnessed tonight, it is  symptomatic of your entire generation.
(almost speechless) You are some piece of work, Leopold.
Now I do not wish to get personal...
Charlie bursts into ironic laughter and looks at the old  woman. She rolls her eyes.
But you have been of great assistance  to me and I feel this is one area  where I can be of some real help.
I'm fascinated. Go on.
Now, why was I successful with this  young lady and why did you so  miserably fail?
What makes you think she likes you?
Well she gave me the number of her  telephone and I assumed it meant...
Go on.
As I see it, the girl hasn't an  inkling of your intentions. And it's  no wonder. You, Charles, are a Merry  Andrew.
A what?
A Merry Andrew.
I am not!!

Everything plays like a farce to  you. The more wit, the less courage.  I believe the modern woman desires  passion, protection, sensitivity. No  woman wants to be romanced by a  buffoon. (the old woman shakes  her head) Banter and repartee are fine but you  must add to that a different sort of  playfulness.
You think I should pounce?
I'm saying you must treat her with  respect. Any oaf can attempt a crude  pass. A woman of Kate's stature would  never respond to an artificial tactic.
Kate?
What?
You said Kate.
I did not.
Yes you did. Didn't he say Kate?
The old woman nods.
We are discussing your problem.
Not anymore. You like my sister.
Charles...
She has trouble with men, you know.
Perhaps she has not met the right  one.
She has met the right one. HUNDREDS  of times. But she pulls back. She  cuts herself off. You turn around  and suddenly you're dating a Sphinx.
One never can tell.
Does Kate know how you feel?
No...
Have you made your intentions known  to her?
No...
Who's the Merry Andrew now?! I think  you're all talk and no action. What  are you waiting for?
I do not know if there is a future  in it.
Well Leopold, no one ever does...

Kate enters with an arm load of Leopold's discarded cloth She drops them on his bed and begins to hang them in his  closet. A notebook falls from his pants pocket. She puts it on th bureau. A beat. She quickly picks it up, sits on the edge the bed and starts to read.
(reading out loud) Royal family -- Uncouth. Making Out --  slow soulful kissing... Woman as  equals??
She flips a page.
Who drove the Chevy to the levy and  why was it dry?
Kate smiles. She flips the page.

Eyes shine when she talks about...  science. Raises her voice when she  knows she's wrong. BOSSY, BOSSY,  BOSSY. Lose my train of thought when  I see her smile. Most beautiful when  she's angry. Honorable heart...  Peasant feet.
The front door is heard slamming. Kate, alarmed, stuffs t notebook back in Leopold's pocket. She races to the door; glances back at the notebook, turns off the light and scu from the room.
The corridor is darkly lit. Kate leaves the bathroom as  Leopold enters. They collide and separate but remain clos together. Both are dressed in pajamas and speak softly.
Ooops. Bread and butter.
What's that?
Bread and butter. It's an old  saying... Well not to you I guess.  You say it when you pass someone in  a cramped space. As close as bread  and butter.
I see.
So. Did you have a good time last  night?
It was very interesting.
Did you find that person of quality?
Leopold looks at her a moment.
Yes. I did.
Well... fine. (there is a pause) I guess it's time to turn in.
Yes.
Goodnight.
She reaches her door. Leopold stops her.
Kate?
She turns. Leopold grasps for the words but the habit of  inaction returns.
Goodnight. (he slowly closes the  door)
Charlie stands at Patrice's door with a large painting. H looks over at Leopold hiding the next doorway over. Charl knocks. She opens the door.
Hi. I brought you some flowers.
He hands her the flower filled painting.
Charlie!
Miss Wochuchowski? I was wondering  if you would do me the great honor  of accompanying me to the cinema  tonight. And allowing me the privilege  of escorting you to dinner afterwards.
Patrice shyly studies the painting.
It's beautiful.
Charlie quickly looks at Leopold pleadingly. He really do not want to say this next part. Leopold, however, is adam
(deadpan) Gracing me with your conversation  and company would mean the world to  me.
There is a long pause. Patrice watches Charlie in disbeli
7:00 is fine. I'll call for you then.
They smile at each other for a long moment.
(silently mouthing) Goodbye.
Goodbye. (she closes the door) It worked!
Of course it did.
Leopold, I... I'm... I have no idea  what to do next!
Charles. Leave everything to me.
Not so fast, buddy. You're next.
Kate is by the bookshelf gathering reference books on tim and space. Leopold enters. He is suddenly embarrassed and doesn't know how to proceed.
Good morning.
Good morning. You're up early.
She moves to her computer on the other side of the room.  Leopold follows. Before she can sit down, Leopold pulls o her chair. She falls to the ground. He rushes to her side immediately.
I'm terribly sorry!!
Happens all the time...
She opens a reference book and slowly begins typing at he computer. There is a pause.
Dr. Coles?... ah, Kate? I was  wondering...
She stops working and looks at Leopold.
What it is you're working on.
Oh. It's my computer.
She resumes her work.
I see. Actually I meant the work  itself.
I'm researching the correlations  between your time and the present.
Leopold stares blankly.
I'm TRYING to get you home, Leopold.
Oh.
Charlie peaks in, signaling Leopold, spurring him on.
I have never seen a woman work as  diligently and extensively before.
It's made me the man I am today.
It's quite a beautiful day, have you  noticed? Perhaps you would permit  yourself some time off and grant me  the privilege of escorting you around  the city this fine Spring afternoon.
Oh, I'd love to but I can't. I've  got too much work to do. Ask Charlie  though. He'll go with you.
I'm afraid it really wouldn't be the  same. It is YOUR company I am seeking.
Surprised, Kate turns around and looks at Leopold.
(gently) Oh, Leopold. I'm so sorry. I can't.
I see. Some other time then.
Yes... Thank you.

Leopold sits at the far end of the room. Kate takes a mom then resumes typing. She STOPS and sits back in her chair After a long moment, she subtly unplugs the computer with her foot and starts banging on the top of it.
Oh for crying out loud. Would you  look at this? Leopold? The computer's  on the blink again. (she bangs harder) Cheap piece of equipment. I can't...
Maybe if you...
NO, no, it does this all the time.  Just have to wait it out.
I see.
Darn.
...Perhaps it is a sign?
Oh, you think? (she smiles at Leopold)
Leopold trots his horse expertly along the horse path. Ka follows, clutching the horses neck, bouncing like a clown
I... I must have gotten a funny  horse...
Leopold turns and rides around Kate.
Allow me.

Bethesda fountain. Boats on Central Park Lake. Couples in Sheeps Meadow. Holding the reins of Kate's horse in one hand, Leopold gr Kate's waist with the other as they ride a single horse  through the greenery of Central Park.
A revival house. On the Marquee: "The Tenuous Duke" starr Ronald Coleman.

Kate and Leopold eat popcorn, Milk Duds, M & M's, and lar drinks. The lights go down and the movie begins. The enormity of the medium strikes Leopold at once. He  involuntarily leans back in his chair grabbing Kate's  shoulder, watching attentively. After a bit:
Is that supposed to be my hair? Do  you see how they think my hair looks?
Kate looks over at Leopold and nods. Through his eyes, sh too experiences movies for the first time. She moves clos to him.
Grammercy Park, The Guggenheim Museum, Central Park Plaza The Metropolitan Museum.
Kate and Leopold bound up the steps, entering the museum.
Modern art exhibit. Leopold stares blankly at an empty wh canvas. He turns to Kate questioningly.
That's simplicity in it's purest  form. It speaks volumes in it's  nothingness. Whiteness representing  emptiness. Hopelessness. It's bleak.  Bleak!
Leopold eyes the painting skeptically. They move to the n object d'art. A toilet.
Aaand this represents...?
They burst into giddy laughter.
Absolutely nothing.
They round the corner, moving to the next room. Leopold's smile fades. CLOSE UP: A painting of privileged Victorian society. Shaken, he gazes at a painting in a dream-like state.
(very quietly) I'd almost forgotten how beautiful  it was. Truly. Beautiful.
Kate smiles sadly at Leopold. They slowly walk out.
We hear keys in the lock and laughter outside as Kate and Leopold enter.
(laughing) M & M's, CBS, FBI.
VIP, VHS, VCR.
They collapse on the couch.
Ah, JFK, PDQ, XYZ.
I don't know. K.D. Lang.
I don't know how you keep up with  it. I'm exhausted.
So am I.

I'll tell you what. Why don't I  prepare dinner tomorrow night? I  never have before. I mean even before  I hit town. "Hit town" How's that? I  can't imagine what it'll taste like,  but I don't think it will be any  worse than your cooking.
Leopold, I have a date tomorrow night.
I see.
A blind date.
Oh, I'm so sorry.
No, that just means I haven't met  him before. It was set up through  friends.
Ah!
A hazard of single life... I'm turning  in.
Kate gets up. Leopold automatically stands.
Another time then.
I'm sorry.
It's quite all right.
As she gets to the door, she stops.
Leopold? I had a wonderful time today.  I can't remember the last time I  took the day off and just played.  I'd forgotten how beautiful this  city can be... I want to thank you  for that.
The pleasure was mine.
Kate smiles at Leopold and goes out.
Charlie, in a tie, is standing with Leopold at the dining room table. Kate wearing too much makeup for her date, ru into the bathroom in a BRIGHT RED DRESS.
It's a very fancy restaurant, Leopold.  Are you sure you can teach me  everything there is to know?
(from the bathroom) Just don't swipe the silverware and  give yourself away.
Nobody's talking to you.
It is very simple. I will be your  date. Just behave as you normally  would and I'll correct you along the  way. Now, escort me in.

Charlie and Leopold move across the room. After a beat,  Charlie magnanimously gestures for Leopold to go first.  Leopold gives his approval. Kate rushes out of the bathro in a tight BLACK dress. Leopold and Charlie elegantly walk to the table. Charlie  sits down, pleased. Leopold remains standing, incensed.
Now what?
Leopold takes a cloth napkin, hits Charlie upside the hea Hard.
Pull the chair for a lady! Clod.
No name calling.
(to Kate) Well, really!
Charlie stands up and pulls out the chair. As Leopold sit Charlie pushes the chair in to hard.
You're not shoveling coal into a  furnace, Charles. Glide the chair in  gently. Gently. Try it again.
Charlie gently glides Leopold to the table. He remains  standing, not sure what to do next.
Well, sit down!
Now don't burst a vein or anything,  but there are quite a few knives and  forks here. How do I know what each  one's for?
Merely start from the outside and  work your way in.
What kind of beer should I order?
Beer!
I WAS KIDDING!
How do I look?
Leopold and Charlie stand. Kate poses in the gown picked by Leopold. Leopold smiles brightly.
You look exquisite, Katherine.
(almost sadly) Thank you, Leopold.
She looks at Leopold not knowing what to say. Finally
This is a tie I'm wearing.
You look very nice, Charlie.
Yes. I know.
The doorbell rings.
That must be him.
Your bland date?
Blind date.
Remember to breathe, Kate. And don't  use to many big words. You'll scare  the poor slob away.
(moving to the door) This is always the scary part. (she sings) "Open the door to my, Mystery Date."
She opens the door and looks straight up. Leopold and Cha peer in closer to get a better look. In the doorway stand LARRY, great looking, very tall, a winner.
Hi. Kate?
Larry?
Kate turns back to the others with a frozen smile.
Well, I'm off.
(giving Larry the  once over) Kate, may I have a word with you?
Now?
Yes. (as they cross the  room) I DON'T like the look of him.
What are you talking about?
Cad. I can spot one a mile away. (he helps her with  her coat) I shall escort you out myself. I  will act as your chaperone.
That isn't necessary. I'll be fine.
It is no trouble.
Goodnight, Leopold.
But...
Goodnight.
She is gone. Leopold stares after her, dejected.
Kate and Larry are led to their table. Larry sits down. K remains standing.
(friendly) Sit down.
(sighs) Thank you. (she sits)
So. How am I doing?
I beg your pardon?
How am I doing? First date. You  pleased? You disappointed?
Undecided.
I see.
He snaps his fingers to get the waiters attention startli Kate. She laughs nervously.
So. What did Jeannie say about me?
About you? Ah, she said you were  tall.
And nice looking.
Thank you.
Thank her. And that you persevere  ardently on Wall Street.
Well, I work there...
(after a beat) That must be very interesting.
(laughing) You've obviously never worked on  Wall Street.
(laughing along for  the hell of it) No.
Their laughter subsides. After a beat:
What else did Jeannie say about me?

The Maitre d' of this very fancy restaurant shows Charlie and Patrice to their seats. Charlie motions Patrice to go first just as Leopold has instructed. The Maitre de pulls out Patrice's chair. Charlie gives hi look to back off. Charlie effortlessly glides Patrice to table and takes his seat.
Have I told you how much I liked  your painting?
(beaming) Twice.
If you get tired of hearing about  it, let me know. I have to admit I  was sort of surprised when you called.  I didn't think you liked me, Charlie.
When I first saw you, I thought... (he makes his jaw  drop down to the  floor)
What do you think now?
Charlie smiles and places her hand over his heart. Then h makes his jaw drop again. Patrice laughs happily.
Kate and Larry are eating their dinner.
Aaand that's about all Jeannie said.  What did Jeannie say about me?
(smiling) She said you were enormously sexy,  had a great body, but you don't put  out.
Quite a compelling portrait.
(turning on the charm) Would you say it's an accurate  portrait?
(leaning into Larry) A masterpiece.
Leopold slowly carries a dinner tray to the dinning room  table. He moves to the window and looks out. After a whil he pours a glass of wine.
As they eat their dinner Larry drones on.
So this guy wants to invest $50,000  in a stock that's no good. Here's  what I do...

Kate stares absentmindedly at Larry, her mind somewhere e She looks down at the fork in her hand. She switches to t proper one, reflecting on Leopold's etiquette. She notice her napkin lying flat on the table. She reaches for it.
Leopold unfolds his napkin and puts it on his lap. He beg to eat his dinner. Slowly. Elegantly. Alone.
Kate places the napkin on her lap. She stares at it a lon while. Finally she looks up at Larry.
I'm telling you the guy was a DICK!  A total ASSHOLE!
(jarred awake) Who?
Jeff Murray. The guy I've been talking  about. Hello?
(realizing her feelings  for Leopold, smiling  radiantly at Larry) Goodbye.
Then as she leaves, a parting shot.
Don't get up.
Sound of keys in the lock, then Kate bursts through the d
Leopold?
The living room is dark and empty. She goes through the l room, past the hallway, into the bedroom.
Leopold?
His bedroom is empty. He is not there.
Oh, Leopold...

She runs into Charlie's studio and stops short. Next to Charlie's stern paintings, Leopold's portrait of  Kate shines in the moonlight. She wears an antique dress. She is lovely. Kate sees herself as Leopold sees her and touched. She turns and collides head on with Leopold.
Oh!
Bread and butter.
He is wearing gloves and an apron. He rubs his bruised he inadvertently leaving a trail of suds along his face.
You're back early. Did you enjoy  your date?
(happily) No.
She moves in close, trying to remove the soap from his fa
Here, you've got some...
He wipes his face making it much worse.
Is it gone?
(laughing) No.
She uses the apron to wipe away the soap. They gaze at ea other and become serious.

(softly) A funny thing happened to me on my  bland date this evening, Leopold. I  really can't explain it. This puffed- up, puritanical, blundering, greenhorn  kept popping into my mind all night  long at the most inopportune times.  I couldn't get rid of him.
How inconsiderate.

Yeah, it was. The harder I tried,  the more persistent he became. He's  conceited and inflated and unseasoned  and it doesn't seem to matter...  He's 134 years old but I can't get  him out of my head.
Is he there right now?
Right here. Larger than life.
I'll protect you...
They kiss. A long romantic passionate kiss.
Dr. Coles, would you grant me license  to dine with you tomorrow evening at  eight o'clock?
Permission granted.
Until tomorrow, then.
They separate. A beat. Leopold gestures for Kate to go fi They head down the hallway together into their separate r

The table clock chimes eight times. Leopold enters from t kitchen dressed perfectly in the most UP TO DATE style. H carries a casserole dish. A second later Kate enters from the hallway. She is weari an OLD FASHIONED, ANTIQUE DRESS. She looks lovely.
(a little startled) You look beautiful.
YOU do. What have you got there?
Leopold opens the casserole dish.
Hamburger Helper!
I know you like it.
Kate smiles. She looks behind him into the kitchen. A COL MESS. Leopold lights the candles and pulls out her chair. This time she's prepared. He slides her chair to the tabl

head_text.subj: INT. LIVING ROOM, LATER THAT NIGHT

text: The candles have burned down, casting a romantic glow  throughout the apartment. Louis Armstrong's "What a Wonde World" plays. Kate and Leopold sit on the couch sipping w
Tell me more.
Um, where was I? So after my father  died I had to go to work.
Have you had many jobs?

Many. I got fired from all of them.  I'm the most unskilled person I know.  But they were just survival jobs  while I was still in school. I always  knew I wanted to go into science  like my father. And I did.
Do you miss him?
I think about him every day. He was  courtly, just like you.
I think you are a remarkable woman  Katherine Coles.
You just don't get out much. You'd  be surprised how remarkable I'm not.
No, it is you who would be surprised.
They kiss. Anxiously they stare into each other's eyes. T kiss again. Slowly, Kate leads him to her bedroom door. T look at each other, deciding. Deliberately, cautiously, Kate opens the door.
Kate...
Kate puts her fingers over Leopold's lips. Gently she lea him inside. They slowly embrace as the door closes.
Sunlight floods the room. Clothes are scattered about. Tw figures lie curled up together sleeping in bed. One of th figures rolls around. The covers are pulled back revealin
Good morning.
Morning.
They kiss.

Leopold wearing a bathrobe is pouring coffee. The table i set for a huge breakfast. Kate also in a robe enters from the hallway. There is a moment of awkwardness as they see each other for the first time.
Morning.
Good morning.
They kiss shyly. Kate notices the feast.
Look what you've done!
It's nothing.
Nothing? My own mother never made me  a breakfast like this.
I will have to have a talk with her.
Leopold...
Kate...
About last night...
Please sit down.
He pulls out a chair for her and kneels beside her.

Kate, I had never before been a  considerate man. I had, with  astonishing complacency, squandered  my life, waiting for some incentive  to force me into action. You have  made me see how rare our time here  really is. I am most beholden to you  Kate. And always will be.
I sense the word "BUT" entering into  this any minute now.
Leopold takes her hands in his. She looks at him defensiv bracing for worst.
Do me the honor Katherine, of becoming  my wife.
Kate lets out a very girlish, high pitched scream
Shall I take that as a "yes"?
Leopold! Did you just ask me to marry  you?
I love you, Kate.
That's entirely beside the point...  You're moving way too fast here.  Shouldn't we date first? I mean it's  obvious the first one went well...
Where I come from that's pretty much  the way it works.
Leopold, even though last night we...  loved each other, that doesn't mean  this morning we're engaged. It just  doesn't work that way now.

(taking a ring off  his fingers and  placing it on hers) I have loved you since I first set  eyes on you. I cannot imagine my  life without you beside me. I want  to marry you, Kate and make an honest  woman of you.
Oh Leopold, sit down.
They switch places. Leopold sits and Kate kneels beside h

Relationships these days are much  more complicated than that. Women  today have certain freedoms that men  have been taking advantage of for  centuries. You must have been aware  of that. If you think about it  clearly, it should be obvious to you  that marriage between us is out of  the question.
Do you not love me Kate?
(almost inaudible) Don't ever think that...
Then consider my proposal.
I'll think it over but I can tell  you now the answer is...
He kisses her. It's impressive.
(out of breath) Possibly.
(a knowing smile) I need you beside me. I will not  give up easily.
(smiling) Do what you have to do...
Charlie enters. Kate and Leopold become extremely  selfconscious.
Morning.
(too casual and too  chipper) Morning!
Charlie is immediately aware that something is not quite  right. He studies the two of them and nonchalant sits at table. Kate and Leopold serve themselves breakfast.
(to Kate) Coffee?
Kate nods. As Leopold pours, they look at each other shyl
(after a pause) I would like some coffee.
Of course. Say when.
She pours Charlie's coffee until it overflows.
(deadpan) When.
Sorry.

As Kate wipes up the table, Charlie notices her ring. He  eyes Leopold suspiciously. Leopold concentrates on his pl Charlie gives Kate a questioning glance. She smiles at hi looking both innocent and guilty at the same time. After beat:
Uh huh.
All smile privately and sip their coffee without another  word.
Buried behind open books and crumpled up paper, Kate labo in earnest. She stops suddenly, almost violently, and studies the not in front of her. The coffee cup falls from her hand and  breaks.
(calling from her  office) Kate, are you all right?
Fine! I'm fine.

She covers her papers and self consciously cleans up her  mess. She sits down slowly and peeks at her notes. She ha SOLVED THE PUZZLE that will send Leopold back. She looks up in disbelief and glances through her window  around the lab. Everyone is hard at work. Helplessly, she stares back at the paper on her desk. She pulls open her drawer and takes out the picture of  Carlson. She stares at it for a long time. She opens her  mouth to call for the others, stops, and looks at the pho Slowly, with great indecision, Kate crumples up the paper She returns the picture to the drawer. After a long momen she opens a book, feigning research, her mind a million m away.

Leopold and Kate sit on her bed watching David Lettering. Kate clutches her pillow close to her. She looks over at  Leopold concentrating on the TV with furrowed brow. She s sadly. She takes her pillow and flings it off her bed. Sh snuggles up to Leopold. They watch TV. Together.
Central Park in full bloom, Botanical Gardens, The Frock  Museum.
Leopold and Kate eat lunch. Leopold scans a newspaper. On the TV over the bar, Bob Dole is speaking out against gun control.

Public office is apparently still  the last refuge for the incompetent.  Show me a man who does not want his  gun registered and I'll show you a  man who should not own a gun. What  is a pee-pee girl?
What are you reading?
The Village Voice. After much  consideration, I have decided it is  time I join the work force.
As a pee-pee girl?
Perhaps not that, but I am determined  to acquire honest employment.
Leopold, I don't know if that's such  a good idea.
Kate, my life back home was beneficial  to no one. I want my new life to  have value. I won't make the same  mistakes twice.
You have to be patient.
I could conceivably wait my whole  life away.
You're awfully cute when you get  causey.
I will not waste any more time. I  must make a difference.
Customers fill the aisles. In the center of it all, Leopo is hard at work. He holds a bottle of perfume.
Try our fragrance? Would you like to  try our new fragrance today?
What is it?
It is called, POISON.
He squirts some at her.
Oh! I don't think so. Have you got  PASSION?
I beg your pardon?
Elizabeth Taylor's Passion?
Next aisle over.
She leaves. Leopold looks after her.
(after a beat) Give your mother-in-law what she  really deserves this season. Give  her some POISON.
The doctors enter Kate's office and closes the door.
Hi. (the doctors remain  silent) What's the matter?
There is a long pause. Slowly Kate realizes the doctors a on to her. She puts down her pen.
So you know.
We had to go through your computer  to access information. Your  calculations have been verified and  the final course has been set. Leopold  goes back a week from Friday 1:17  a.m.
How long were you going to keep it a  secret, Kate?
Were you even going to tell us at  all?
I'm not sure.
Not sure? What can you be thinking?  You can't alter the course of history  and assume everything will be okay.  It won't be. He has his own destiny  to fulfill in his own time.
(quietly) You don't understand.
(gently) He's going back, Kate.
It's over.
Kate nods. The doctors slowly leave the room and close th door. Just the sound of the clock ticking. Kate sits at her desk very still.
No... No, no, no.
Charlie knocks and enters.
There you are. I've only been  hollering for the last...
